sentences.chinese: 高祖，沛豐邑中陽裏人，姓劉氏，字季。
sentences.literal: Gao Zu was from Zhongyangli in Feng township, Pei, with the surname Liu and given name Ji.

sentences.chinese: 父曰太公，母曰劉媼。
sentences.literal: His father was called the Grand Duke; his mother was called Dame Liu.

sentences.chinese: 其先劉媼嘗息大澤之陂，夢與神遇。
sentences.literal: Previously his mother Dame Liu was resting by the embankment of a great marsh and dreamed she encountered a spirit.

sentences.chinese: 是時雷電晦冥，太公往視，則見蛟龍於其上。
sentences.literal: At that time there was thunder and lightning with darkness; the Grand Duke went to look and saw a scaly dragon above her.

sentences.chinese: 已而有身，遂產高祖。
sentences.literal: Soon after she became pregnant and gave birth to Gao Zu.

sentences.chinese: 高祖為人，隆準而龍顏，美須髯，左股有七十二黑子。
sentences.literal: Gao Zu as a person had a high-bridged nose and dragon-like countenance, fine whiskers and beard, and seventy-two black moles on his left thigh.

sentences.chinese: 仁而愛人，喜施，意豁如也。
sentences.literal: He was benevolent and loved people, delighted in giving, and his spirit was open and expansive.

sentences.chinese: 常有大度，不事家人生產作業。
sentences.literal: He always had a generous nature and did not attend to his family's productive work.

sentences.chinese: 及壯，試為吏，為泗水亭長，廷中吏無所不狎侮，好酒及色。
sentences.literal: When he grew up, he tested for official service and became Pavilion Head of Sishui; among the clerks of the court there was none he did not treat familiarly or make sport of; he loved wine and women.

sentences.chinese: 常從王媼、武負貰酒，醉臥，武負、王媼見其上常有龍，怪之。
sentences.literal: He often bought wine on credit from Dame Wang and Wu Fu; when drunk and lying down, Wu Fu and Dame Wang saw that above him there was always a dragon—they found this strange.

sentences.chinese: 高祖每酤留飲，酒讎數倍。
sentences.literal: Whenever Gao Zu bought and lingered drinking, the wine debt would be multiplied several times.

sentences.chinese: 及見怪，歲竟，此兩家常折券棄責。
sentences.literal: When they saw these strange signs, at year's end these two households would always tear up the debt markers and forgive the debt.

sentences.chinese: 高祖常繇咸陽，縱觀，觀秦皇帝，喟然太息曰：「嗟乎，大丈夫當如此也！」
sentences.literal: Gao Zu once went on corvée duty to Xianyang and took the opportunity to observe; seeing the Emperor of Qin, he sighed deeply and said: "Ah, a great man should be like this!"

sentences.chinese: 單父人呂公善沛令，避仇從之客，因家沛焉。
sentences.literal: Lü Gong of Shanfu was on good terms with the Pei magistrate; fleeing from a vendetta he came to lodge with him and consequently made his home in Pei.

sentences.chinese: 沛中豪桀吏聞令有重客，皆往賀。
sentences.literal: The heroic gentlemen and officials of Pei heard that the magistrate had an important guest and all went to offer congratulations.

sentences.chinese: 蕭何為主吏，主進，令諸大夫曰：「進不滿千錢，坐之堂下。」
sentences.literal: Xiao He was the supervising clerk in charge of reception; he issued orders to all the gentlemen saying: "Those whose gifts are less than a thousand cash shall sit in the lower hall."

sentences.chinese: 高祖為亭長，素易諸吏，乃紿為謁曰「賀錢萬」，實不持一錢。
sentences.literal: Gao Zu as Pavilion Head had always treated the officials casually, so he falsely wrote on his visiting card 'Gift of ten thousand cash,' though he actually carried not a single coin.

sentences.chinese: 謁入，呂公大驚，起，迎之門。
sentences.literal: When the card was sent in, Lü Gong was greatly surprised, rose, and welcomed him at the gate.

sentences.chinese: 呂公者，好相人，見高祖狀貌，因重敬之，引入坐。
sentences.literal: Lü Gong liked reading people's physiognomy; seeing Gao Zu's appearance, he consequently held him in high regard, invited him in, and seated him.

sentences.chinese: 蕭何曰：「劉季固多大言，少成事。」
sentences.literal: Xiao He said: "Liu Ji is always full of grand talk but accomplishes little."

sentences.chinese: 高祖因狎侮諸客，遂坐上坐，無所詘。
sentences.literal: Gao Zu then treated the guests familiarly and sat in the seat of honor without any humility.

sentences.chinese: 酒闌，呂公因目固留高祖。
sentences.literal: When wine was exhausted, Lü Gong signaled with eyes to firmly keep Gao Zu.

sentences.chinese: 高祖竟酒，後。
sentences.literal: Gao Zu finished the wine and remained after.

sentences.chinese: 呂公曰：「臣少好相人，相人多矣，無如季相，願季自愛。
sentences.literal: Lü Gong said: "I have long liked reading physiognomy and have read many people, but none compare to Ji's; I hope Ji will take care of himself.

sentences.chinese: 臣有息女，願為季箕帚妾。」
sentences.literal: I have a daughter and wish her to be Ji's humble wife."

sentences.chinese: 酒罷，呂媼怒呂公曰：「公始常欲奇此女，與貴人。
sentences.literal: When the wine ended, Dame Lü was angry at Lü Gong, saying: "You always wanted to treat this daughter as exceptional and give her to a noble person.

sentences.chinese: 沛令善公，求之不與，何自妄許與劉季？」
sentences.literal: The Pei magistrate is on good terms with you and sought her but you did not give her—why do you rashly promise her to Liu Ji?"

sentences.chinese: 呂公曰：「此非兒女子所知也。」
sentences.literal: Lü Gong said: "This is not something children and women can understand."

sentences.chinese: 卒與劉季。
sentences.literal: He finally gave her to Liu Ji.

sentences.chinese: 呂公女乃呂后也，生孝惠帝、魯元公主。
sentences.literal: Lü Gong's daughter was Empress Lü; she gave birth to Emperor Xiaohui and Princess Lu Yuan.

sentences.chinese: 高祖為亭長時，常告歸之田。
sentences.literal: When Gao Zu was Pavilion Head, he would often request leave to return to his fields.

sentences.chinese: 呂后與兩子居田中耨，有一老父過請飲，呂后因餔之。
sentences.literal: Empress Lü with her two children were in the fields weeding when an old man passed by and requested a drink; Empress Lü consequently fed him.

sentences.chinese: 老父相呂后曰：「夫人天下貴人。」
sentences.literal: The old man read Empress Lü's physiognomy and said: "Madam will be the most noble person under Heaven."

sentences.chinese: 令相兩子，見孝惠，曰：「夫人所以貴者，乃此男也。」
sentences.literal: He asked to read the two children's physiognomy; seeing Xiaohui, he said: "The reason Madam will be noble is because of this boy."

sentences.chinese: 相魯元，亦皆貴。
sentences.literal: Reading Lu Yuan's physiognomy, she would also be noble.

sentences.chinese: 老父已去，高祖適從旁舍來，呂后具言客有過，相我子母皆大貴。
sentences.literal: After the old man left, Gao Zu happened to come from a neighboring house; Empress Lü fully told him that a guest had passed by and read the physiognomy of her and the children, all predicting great nobility.

sentences.chinese: 高祖問，曰：「未遠。」
sentences.literal: Gao Zu asked where he was; she said: "Not far."

sentences.chinese: 乃追及，問老父。
sentences.literal: He then pursued and caught up with the old man and questioned him.

sentences.chinese: 老父曰：「鄉者夫人嬰兒皆似君，君相貴不可言。」
sentences.literal: The old man said: "Earlier your wife and children all resemble you; your physiognomy indicates nobility beyond description."

sentences.chinese: 高祖乃謝曰：「誠如父言，不敢忘德。」
sentences.literal: Gao Zu then bowed and said: "If it is truly as you say, I dare not forget this kindness."

sentences.chinese: 及高祖貴，遂不知老父處。
sentences.literal: When Gao Zu became noble, they never found where the old man was.

sentences.chinese: 高祖為亭長，乃以竹皮為冠，令求盜之薛治之，時時冠之，及貴常冠，所謂「劉氏冠」乃是也。
sentences.literal: When Gao Zu was Pavilion Head, he made a cap of bamboo bark and had the cap-maker of Xue craft it; he wore it from time to time, and when he became noble he always wore it—the so-called 'Liu cap' is this.

sentences.chinese: 高祖以亭長為縣送徒酈山，徒多道亡。
sentences.literal: As Pavilion Head, Gao Zu escorted convicts for the county to Mount Li; many escaped on the road.

sentences.chinese: 自度比至皆亡之，到豐西澤中，止飲，夜乃解縱所送徒。
sentences.literal: He estimated that by the time they arrived all would have fled, so reaching the marshes west of Feng, he stopped to drink, and at night released all the convicts he was escorting.

sentences.chinese: 曰：「公等皆去，吾亦從此逝矣！」
sentences.literal: He said: "You may all go; I too will depart from here!"

sentences.chinese: 徒中壯士願從者十餘人。
sentences.literal: Among the convicts over ten brave men wished to follow him.

sentences.chinese: 高祖被酒，夜徑澤中，令一人行前。
sentences.literal: Gao Zu, intoxicated, traveled by night through the marshes and ordered one man to go ahead.

sentences.chinese: 行前者還報曰：「前有大蛇當徑，願還。」
sentences.literal: The man going ahead returned and reported: "There is a great snake blocking the path ahead; we should turn back."

sentences.chinese: 高祖醉，曰：「壯士行，何畏！」
sentences.literal: Gao Zu, drunk, said: "A brave man goes forward—what is there to fear!"

sentences.chinese: 乃前，拔劍擊斬蛇。
sentences.literal: He then went forward, drew his sword, and struck and beheaded the snake.
